28 lbs. of processor for...this Field Trip! The Microsoft Archives
Run for your lives! Field Trip! The Microsoft Archives
A life-sized Clippy costume, encased in plastic. Biding its time. Field Trip! The Microsoft Archives

This was the Altair 8800, similar to the model that inspired Bill Gates and Paul Allen when they saw it on the cover of Popular Electronics in 1975.  But this is the 8800b – a sort of “version 2.0” of this device.  Perhaps it had an extra switch. Field Trip! The Microsoft Archives
This Compaq “portable” weighs in at 28 lbs. (12.7 Kg) Field Trip! The Microsoft Archives

This Xbox was shown when the project was first revealed at the Game Developer’s Conference in 2000 – It was clear at the time that this would not be the final hardware design. Field Trip! The Microsoft Archives
An early Microsoft logo used on consumer products. Makes us look like a heavy metal band. Field Trip! The Microsoft Archives
No, that’s not a tiny coffee cup. It’s an 8 inch floppy! Field Trip! The Microsoft Archives

Steve, who works in Microsoft sales, supports the InterAmerican Restoration Corporation: “Inter-Urban Restoration Corporation of Honduras has built over 3,000 homes, children’s home, a medical clinic serving 10,000 patients a year, and is building a women’s trade-training center.”

Be a #GivingHero: Join Microsoft employees who support the IRC and other youth-oriented causes: http://msft.it/6185jSx5 Timeline Photos

Tom, a Microsoft engineer, supports Xbot Robotics: “How could I possibly have more fun while doing more good? I love sharing my passion for engineering and giving kids a better chance at college and a great career.”

Be a #GivingHero: Join Microsoft employees who support Xbot Robotics and other youth causes: http://msft.it/6182jooy Timeline Photos

Theo, a Microsoft Store employee, supports The Healing Circle 'Victory over Child Abuse' camps: “The Healing Circle camps are a safe place where you don't have to worry about your history and can just be a kid.” 

Be a #GivingHero: Join Microsoft employees supporting The Healing Circle and other youth causes: http://msft.it/6182jmgq Timeline Photos

Poorvi, a Microsoft engineer, supports the College Success Foundation: “I was seven when I was first introduced to a computer and I struggled badly in my first programming class. Today, I focus on involving students, especially girls, by explaining OOPS concepts to them in real life situations.”

Be a #GivingHero: Join Microsoft employees who support the College Success Foundation and inspire students to pursue STEM degrees: http://msft.it/6185jcN5 Timeline Photos

Velu, a Microsoft engineer, supports ISHA: “The moment I started working at Microsoft, I began supporting the education of a girl child in India. Bala Bavani, now in 5th grade, is very much inclined to become a teacher, loves math, and wants to give back to her community. As Microsoft is matching my contribution, another girl, Brisilla, now in 4th grade, is also receiving free education.” 

Be a #GivingHero: Join Microsoft employees helping to educate children in India and other youth causes: http://msft.it/6183jg0R Timeline Photos

Katie, a producer at Microsoft supports Knock Foundation: “$25 helps provide lunch for 3 children for a whole year! For many, this is the only meal of the day and incentive for parents to send them to school instead of keeping them home to help with chores.”

Be a #GivingHero: Join Microsoft employees supporting the Knock Foundation and other youth causes: http://msft.it/6187jg0z Timeline Photos

Sonu, a Microsoft program manager, supports Cascade Science Center Foundation: “I dream of a community where children embrace science, technology, engineering and mathematics with open arms. Join our Cascades Science Squad and help design fun, hands-on STEM curriculum or mentor young kids.” 

Be a #GivingHero: Join Microsoft employees helping to bring joy to kids by supporting Cascade Science Center Foundation and other youth causes: http://msft.it/6186jg06 Timeline Photos

“In 1995, when I was 8 my father was diagnosed with HIV. Inspire Youth Project became my extended family.” – Katie, Microsoft Operations PM

Be a #GivingHero: Join Microsoft employees supporting children affected by HIV/AIDS and other youth causes in your community: http://msft.it/6183jboB Timeline Photos

"Microsoft employees at our South Coast Plaza store have joined with community partners to raise over $95K toward a Blind Technology Center to provide support for visually impaired children and their families.” Kelly, Microsoft Store, Costa Mesa, CA

Be a Giving Hero: Join Microsoft employees supporting this and other youth causes in your community: http://msft.it/ghbclc Timeline Photos

“The more I work with Hopelink, the more I see how innovative they are!” Andy, Microsoft engineer, and Hopelink Board Treasurer. 

Be a #GivingHero: Join the Microsoft employees supporting Hopelink and other youth causes in your community: http://msft.it/6189jrnW Timeline Photos

Sarah, a Microsoft store employee in Cincinnati supports Ronald McDonald House: “Twice a month, we make breakfast for families so parents can spend more time with their children." Be a #GivingHero: Join Microsoft employees supporting Ronald McDonald House and other youth causes in your community: http://msft.it/6189jMgF Timeline Photos

Sanjay, a Microsoft employee in Delaware, volunteers with FAME, an organization dedicated to helping kids in grade 7-12 study STEM. Be a #GivingHero. Join Microsoft employees supporting FAME and other youth causes in your community: http://msft.it/6188jzFO Timeline Photos

Jason, a Microsoft employee in Boulder, CO supports the I Have a Dream Foundation: “I wouldn’t be where I am today without them. They adopted my 4th grade class. When our phone was disconnected, they came knocking on my door to make sure I was okay and on track.”

Be a #GivingHero: Join Microsoft employees in their support of the I Have a Dream Foundation and other youth causes in your community: http://msft.it/givinghero Timeline Photos

Monique, a Microsoft Store employee in San Francisco supports GLIDE: “Giving back is healing for the soul. We may not have the money to take care of those with less than we have, but we have the passion." 

Be a #GivingHero: Join the Microsoft employees who support GLIDE and other youth causes in your community: http://msft.it/6187jHHh Timeline Photos

Sandi, a Microsoft employee in Austin supports Urban Roots: “Here in Austin, 1 in 4 children live in food-insecure households. My team harvested 707 pounds of collards, fennel, beets, cabbage, and spinach on Urban Roots’ 3.5-acre urban, sustainable farm. How cool is that?” Be a #GivingHero. Join the Microsoft employees supporting youth causes in your community: http://msft.it/6187jEmz Timeline Photos

Support youth in your community, be a #GivingHero: http://msft.it/6186jBSM

“I was encouraged to excel and achieve big, bold audacious goals. Dream Jamaica inspires students and provides the means by which they can achieve.” Shemiele, a Microsoft Business Manager supports Dream Jamaica, one of the many youth causes we're supporting this month. Timeline Photos
